talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: Senator HILL

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

item.label: (a)
item.para: unreservedly condemns the terrorist atrocities in Bali on 1 October 2005;

item.label: (b)
item.para: extends its sympathy to the families and loved ones of all those who have been killed or injured as a result of the attacks;

item.label: (c)
item.para: expresses on behalf of the Australian community its hope for an early and full recovery of all those injured;

item.label: (d)
item.para: acknowledges and thanks those who assisted in the rescue and relief efforts;

item.label: (e)
item.para: expresses on behalf of the Australian people its solidarity with the people of Bali and the wider Indonesian community at this time of shared grief;

item.label: (f)
item.para: expresses its full support for the Indonesian authorities in their efforts to bring to justice those responsible for this outrage; and

item.label: (g)
item.para: resolves to continue the fight against terrorism in all its forms.

speech.para: Three closely timed explosions took place in Bali at around 7.30 pm on 1 October—one at Kuta Square and two at Jimbaran Bay—causing deaths and injuries to a number of people. Two Australians are confirmed dead: a 16-year-old boy from Western Australia and a 48-year-old woman from New South Wales. Latest reports put the death toll at at least 22, with over 100 injured. Seventeen Australians have been injured, some critically. We also hold grave concerns for another two Australians who have not been seen since the Jimbaran Bay attack. The 17 hospitalised Australians have all been evacuated from Bali by two RAAF military aircraft and four other specialised emergency flights. I might say that Qantas was also of considerable assistance in that regard. We also evacuated one injured Indonesian, accompanied by his wife, and two injured Japanese nationals to Darwin for medical treatment.

The emergency response team that arrived in Bali on 2 October continues to work under the direction of our Consul General to manage our response. The team includes consular, medical, counselling, emergency management and bomb-blast specialist personnel from DFAT, the Australian Federal Police, Defence, Centrelink and Emergency Management Australia. A team of AFP disaster victim identification specialists has flown to Bali from Singapore and has been reinforced by officers from Australia. There are currently 35 AFP officers on the ground in Bali assisting the Indonesian authorities.

All Australians will condemn this outrage and, on behalf of the Senate, we extend our condolences to those who have been injured, to their families and friends. We send our best wishes to the injured for their early and complete recovery. As I said in the motion, we thank all who have assisted: the officials, Defence Force members and volunteers. They have all helped with the rescue effort and they continue to help in the aftermath. The response, in my view, has been prompt, efficient, well organised and a great credit to all who have made the effort—and, as I said, that work is ongoing.

The bombs would seem to have been the work of three suicide bombers. Senator Ellison, as Minister for Justice and Customs, will report further on the police investigation and the specific support being given by Australian authorities. The attack is widely believed to be the work of Jemaah Islamiah, or some associated Islamist terrorist group or groups with a common cause. This cause is an extreme interpretation of Islam. It calls for its supporters to create an Islamic state and to fight and destroy non-believers. Thus, destabilising the Indonesian government is a goal; destroying Indonesia’s tourist infrastructure is a goal; and killing innocent people is also a legitimate tool towards achieving that goal.

We have, of course, experienced these attacks before. It is now nearly three years since 88 Australians, and others, lost their lives to a terrorist attack in Bali. We experienced the terrorist attack on our embassy in Jakarta about 12 months ago. We witnessed the terrorist attack on the Marriott Hotel, also in Jakarta. We knew of the possibility of further terrorist attacks. We knew some Jemaah Islamiah leaders were still at large. We knew some explosives within the region remained unaccounted for. We issued travel advisory warnings appropriately. But, again, there was no specific intelligence on a time or place that could have helped prevent the attacks on 1 October, and rarely will that information ever be available. These are elusive targets. We remember the recent experience of the bombings in London, and reflect on the circumstances of the bombings in Madrid and other places in the world where such events have taken place in recent years. It is a global phenomenon, but the loose links between individuals and groups make it particularly hard to combat.

As would be expected, since 11 September 2001 the Australian government has taken a large range of initiatives to provide better protection for Australians, whether in Australia or overseas. The government has systematically reviewed the critical components of Australia’s protection against terrorism, and established a national strategic framework based on the principles of maximum preparedness, comprehensive prevention and effective response. The government has, in fact, invested over $5.6 billion of taxpayers’ funds over a period of eight years to better support these initiatives. For example, $1.2 billion has been provided to intelligence agencies, including a $240 million boost over four years in this last budget in additional resources to ASIO, ASIS and others.

We have increased our dissemination of advice to Australian travellers, provided additional security at embassies, provided funding for the national security hotline and increased transport security, including enhanced AFP counter-terrorism first response at security categorised airports and air security officer programs. We have strengthened Customs’ defences. We have invested more in border surveillance, with over $200 million allocated to maritime security since 2004, including the establishment of the Joint Offshore Protection Command. We have introduced explosive trace detection equipment, upgraded emergency services, created the AFP regional cooperation teams—already in the Philippines and Indonesia—and expanded counter-terrorism exercise programs, including multijurisdictional exercises.

Since the first attack in Bali, we have enhanced national counter-terrorism coordination arrangements. We have introduced stronger and more comprehensive terrorism laws, we have improved the resources available to intelligence and law enforcement agencies again, we have introduced strong and layered border controls to minimise the risk of terrorists entering Australia, we have introduced comprehensive new measures to counter potential threats to our domestic and international transport networks, and we have ensured that we have the ability to respond to a terrorist incident, should one occur in this country.

In relation to the particular threat of Jemaah Islamiah within Indonesia and within the region, the government has expanded the AFP network of overseas officers, including 65 members in 32 strategic locations. It has assisted, as we know, in investigations in Indonesia, the Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Spain, Turkey and London. Regional cooperation between law enforcement and intelligence agencies has continued to disrupt JI’s operations and terrorist planning within the region. Of course, within 24 hours of the first Bali attacks, the Australian Federal Police had sent a team of investigators and forensic officers to Bali to assist the Indonesian National Police, establishing a joint investigation team. In fact, at the height of that investigation, in excess of 120 Australian law enforcement personnel were working alongside their Indonesian counterparts.

It is worth reflecting on the fact that the Indonesian courts have convicted a total of 40 people for their involvement in the 2002 Bali bombings. Three have received the death sentence and four, life sentences. The Indonesian courts have also obtained six convictions arising from the Jakarta embassy bombing. Terrorist leaders, JI leaders, such as Hambali and Amrozi are no longer at large. Regional governments have detained over 300 people linked to JI; more than 270 have in fact been detained in Indonesia.

Australia co-hosted the regional counter-terrorism meeting in Bali in February 2004. Twenty-five countries attended, all committed to practical outcomes in terms of lessening this terrorism threat. Since 9-11, Australia has signed 11 bilateral counter-terrorism MOUs—with Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Fiji, Cambodia, East Timor, India, PNG, Brunei and Pakistan—and all are now being progressed. High-level counter-terrorism dialogues have been held with the US and Japan and agreed with the Philippines, and these will build on existing operational relations. ASIO has approved liaison relations with more than 250 agencies. The financial intelligence unit has signed over 30 MOUs globally since 9-11. That is without even mentioning the direct attack upon the Taliban—which was hosting al-Qaeda, the best known of these international terrorist organisations—to which Australia contributed in Afghanistan and to which Australia continues to contribute in terms of strengthening that new democracy and avoiding a resurgence of Taliban activity.

I could go on and remind the Senate of the legislative changes that have been made, all the changes that have been made in relation to transport services within Australia, and the recent initiatives that have been endorsed for further legislative change through the COAG process—and I recognise the states being prepared to assist the national government in that regard. But, despite all of that effort and all of that investment, this threat remains difficult and elusive and, unfortunately, one that is likely to be with us for some time but which we must use every endeavour to combat. So we will continue to do everything possible as a government to safeguard Australians from these threats.

I want to conclude by specifically mentioning Indonesia, which of course has suffered a great deal from not only the threat but also the attacks in recent years. Most of those who died or who were injured in Bali this last weekend were Indonesians. The country has suffered, the Indonesian people have suffered a great deal; it is clearly a threat that is particularly difficult to combat within Indonesia. The Prime Minister has again spoken to President Yudhoyono, who clearly is committed to addressing this threat in the most effective way possible.

It is true that we have asked Indonesia to take further action and we will continue to do so. And, as the Indonesians take further action, we will continue to support them in building their capabilities, whether it is in terms of their laws, their law enforcement capacity or their counter-terrorism capacity. As they take further steps and continue to move against this threat, which is an even greater threat to them than it is to Australia, Australia will stand alongside them. We have done so in the past. We contributed to enhancing the hospital which actually helped save lives last weekend in Bali. On this occasion we have offered further financial assistance, another $1 million, to help Bali cope with this tragedy. We are in this fight together and we will only succeed by working together. For those who have lost their lives, those who are grieving and those who are suffering, we must recommit ourselves to defeating this threat so that the time will come when no more families will grieve over events such as we experienced last weekend. I commend the motion to the Senate.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

talker.name: Evans, Sen Chris
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate
talker.name: Senator CHRIS EVANS

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Labor opposition, I would like to support the condolence motion moved by Senator Hill. Unfortunately, this is something that the Senate has had to do far too often of late. Here we are again mourning the loss of victims of a terrorist attack. We send our sympathies to the families and friends of those killed and injured in Bali at the weekend, the Australians, Indonesians, other nationals and tourists in the region. We remember the victims of these cowardly acts of indiscriminate violence, and I am sure that the thoughts of all Australians at this time are with the families who have suffered this terrible loss. We must send our thanks and support to the people who are leading the Australian relief effort, the Defence people, the AFP, the medical personnel and others who have offered their help.

speech.para: I think most Australians were terribly shocked and saddened when they woke up on Sunday to hear the news of the latest bombings in the tourist heart of Bali. Very few of us would have been unaware that we are approaching the third anniversary of the 2002 Bali bombings at Kuta. Those bombings a year after the 11 September attacks in the United States really brought home to Australians that, in our region, we are facing a new threat to our security and our way of life. Those attacks clearly targeted foreigners enjoying the hospitality of the Balinese but they also targeted the Indonesian people and their government.

Just over a year ago, Australians and Indonesians were again directly targeted in a bombing attack on our embassy in Jakarta. Of course, we have all seen the recent bomb attacks on trains and buses in London which, again, were very close to Australians’ hearts, given the association we have with Great Britain. The increasing frequency of these events does not reduce in any way their savagery and the compassion we feel for those affected. The latest bombings took place on Saturday night at three restaurants that are clearly popular with tourists. It appears that the first bomb went off at about 7.30 pm at a restaurant on Jimbaran Beach. Another went off at another restaurant along the beach very soon afterwards. Minutes later, a third bomb was detonated at Raja’s Bar and Restaurant at Kuta. Clearly, they were designed to maim and kill as many as possible. It appears that the perpetrators had packed the devices with shrapnel and ball bearings to increase the injuries caused by the bombs. The attacks took place at the height of the tourist season in Bali in the middle of school holidays when many Australian tourists were holidaying there, and have come at a time when the Balinese tourist economy was just recovering from the effects of the 2002 bombings. On the latest information, it appears that at least 22 people have died and many more are injured. We understand that the Australian death toll may be as high as four and we know that at least 14 Indonesians have been killed.

Tragically killed was Brendan Fitzgerald, a 16-year-old high school student from my home state of Western Australia. Brendan was from Busselton. Reports suggest he was holidaying in Bali with his father, Terry, and sister, Jessica. They were also seriously injured in the attack. Our thoughts are with them. We wish them a speedy recovery and send our condolences to them and their family for their tragic loss. We also know that the youngest victim of the attack was a four-year-old, a young Indonesian boy dining at Jimbaran Bay with his parents. Among those killed and injured were Australians travelling from Newcastle. Our thoughts go out to the family of Jennifer Williamson, who was among those killed and whose husband, Bruce, was also very seriously injured. I understand that authorities hold very serious concerns for another Australian couple. A large contingent from Newcastle travelling with their children were in Bali on a surfing holiday. They were connected to local schools. It reminds us of the effect on a group that we also experienced in Western Australia with the Kingsley Football Club in the earlier Bali attacks of 2002, which affected a whole community with the toll it took on members of that club.

On a personal note, West Aussies in particular have a connection with Bali. Very few of us have not travelled there and enjoyed holidays. I know a number of senators around the chamber have done that. There is a real connection as West Australians. In a sense, it has become a bit of a rite of passage. For West Australians, your first overseas holiday is to be taken by your parents to Bali. The old days of people going to London in their early 20s has been replaced by a teenage holiday in Bali. I know that was my son’s first overseas trip. As I said, it is a bit of a rite of passage as your first overseas journey. Brendan represented many West Australians and other Australian teenagers on their first overseas holiday. To be cut down at such a young age is a terrible thing. It brought it home to me. I took my two boys there only a couple of years ago. They played soccer on the beach with Balinese children as we waited for our dinner to be cooked at one of the Jimbaran Beach restaurants that was destroyed in the bomb attacks. Lots of us have been there and can imagine ourselves sitting in the same spot. It is all too clear that we could have been there and that the experience of so many Australians makes them very close to the events.

West Australians are used to holidaying there. They go in a relaxed manner. They are very fond of the Balinese and very fond of the environment. There has been a real loss of innocence for Australians in that people can be killed while on holidays in such a lovely and friendly spot. It is also a shame for people who overcame the fear that came after the first bombs went off in Bali, partly due to a commitment to support the Balinese economy and help the Balinese people recover from the tragedy of the earlier bombing. I hope that in time after the second attack people will again return to Bali despite their fears, but I am sure this will have an even longer lasting memory for people because it reinforces their concerns.

On behalf of Labor, I would like to express our thanks to all those who have been involved in the response: the Australian Federal Police personnel in Australia and on the ground in Indonesia; the defence forces; the crews of the C-130s evacuating people; and the various other medical professionals, including some reservists who have been working with the injured. We also pay tribute to the work of our consular staff in Indonesia, who I know from previous experience seem to have been working full time on these things over the last six or seven years.

It is a sad reality of recent times that these personnel have grown very practised in responding to these types of incidents. They do so with great integrity and professionalism, and we thank them for their efforts in extremely daunting circumstances. We are fortunate to have their skills and services at our nation’s disposal and that those skills can be made available to our neighbours and friends. We also, of course, recognise the work of personnel at hospitals in Australia and elsewhere in helping to deal with the victims. As Senator Hill pointed out, there was recognition that the contribution we made to upgrading hospital facilities in Bali unfortunately was useful and was used on this occasion. It at least reinforces the value of that sort of contribution, and I would like to reiterate Labor’s support for the response of the Australian government in providing assistance to those affected by the bombings and to the Indonesian government.

The weekend’s events confirm once again the need to be strong in the face of terror in our region and around the world. Labor believes we must focus attention on the threat presented in South-East Asia and the Pacific. Our policy must include constructive engagement with the governments of the region, addressing the most immediate threats to our security and recognising the areas in which we make our greatest contribution. We have stated in the days since the bombings our hope that the government will encourage the government of Indonesia to outlaw JI. We believe this move would give the Indonesian government greater power to act against the organisation—for example, disrupting its finances and monitoring the activities of its members as well as hindering recruitment. Labor also believes that Australia needs to establish a structured intelligence network in the South-East Asian region. This is a long-term project that would build upon and move beyond our present level of regional cooperation. We believe this is a necessity in the current environment.

I want to say a couple of short things about terrorism and travel advices. I think the easy thing for Australians to say is: ‘We won’t return to Bali. We won’t travel. Our response to this will be to stay at home and withdraw.’ I think that would be the wrong response. It is too easy to retreat to Fortress Australia and hope it does not happen here. I think there are important benefits of travel, including having a world view and overcoming the prejudice, hatred and fear that JI represent. I would hope that it would not discourage Australians from travelling. That is not to say that we should ignore the travel advices—surely, we should not.

If you look at what has happened in the last seven years—I did a bit of a tot-up of the terrorist attacks—there were the US embassy bombings in Africa in 1998 and the 11 September attack on New York, which we all remember so vividly. If you follow the terrorist attacks since then—and this is not an exhaustive list—you have attacks in Singapore, Karachi, Bali, Casablanca, Jakarta, Istanbul, Madrid, Beslan, Jakarta again, Cairo, London, Egypt and Bali again. If you take a decision not to travel to a place where there has been a terrorist attack, where can you go? Where in the world is safe? Where in the world can we travel? The answer of course is that anywhere could be attacked, terrorism does not know any boundaries and nowhere is safe from the threat of terrorism.

In terms of travel warnings, looking at the current site, there are still many warnings on travel to other countries. We have to deal more directly with the reality of Australians’ response to those travel warnings. I know there is an argument about the adequacy of the travel warnings. I do not want to address that today. But the reality is that Australians ignore travel warnings. Minister Abbott was in Bali at the time. I am not critical of him for that. I would have gone if I had had the capacity. The point is that Australians in their thousands go to Bali, to Indonesia, and to a whole range of places where there are travel warnings saying they should not travel. We have got to deal with that reality and not pretend that the warnings in some way protect us from those realities. Australians do travel and they travel to those destinations and, I think rightly, they have made the decision that they will continue to travel. If you go through the list of where there have been attacks, New Zealand looks like the only safe haven. It is important that we review the effectiveness of the travel warnings and travel advices—not in the sense that I suggest they are not accurate. What is the point of having a system that Australians ignore? It does not advance the cause at all.

As I say, I would urge Australians not to retreat to Fortress Australia and not to give up on the fact that we need to encourage people to have a world view, to travel, to broaden their minds and to broaden their sense of being in a global environment as world citizens. This is a threat to all citizens of the world, not just to Australians or Indonesians. I support the government in its motion. On behalf of Labor, we express our condolences to those who have lost loved ones and to those still recovering. We restate our determination to tackle terrorism and the conditions that allow it to grow and we reassert our determination not to be cowed in the face of terrorist tactics.

talk.start.para: —I and my Green colleagues join in the condolences to the families of those who have lost their lives and to the people who have been injured and hurt in so many different ways by the murderous attacks in Bali on Saturday night—the Williamsons, the Fitzgeralds, the other families who are grieving at the moment, the Indonesian families, the Japanese family and the families from elsewhere around the world who have either lost loved ones or are wondering what on earth has happened in the absence of calls.

speech.para: The cowardly and murderous actions of the terrorists have to be stood up to. I want to congratulate all those who are helping to do just that at the moment by their presence in Bali, by the assistance they are giving in so many ways to responding to this murderous attack to both the victims and to tracking down, hopefully with a very early arrest, everybody who was involved in premeditating and carrying out the cowardly bomb explosions in Kuta on Saturday night.

I think I express the point of view of many Australians when I say this: we will not be cowed by terrorism. We will not back down to those who believe they have a mortgage on what is right and who believe that through violence they can intimidate those who have a different point of view, particularly those who believe in democracy, believe in equality of human beings, believe in the right to different points of view and in fact celebrate the diversity of humanity. There is no way that terrorism will have us back off from our determination to make this world a fairer place and from our determination to ensure that all people have a right to their beliefs, to their political avocation, to their culture, to the way they want to nurture their families, their loved ones and their relationships, and to the whole beauty of life on this planet.

We cannot and will not ever be cowed by those who want to put together explosive devices, who want to create mayhem, who want to murder and who want to create fear as a means of moving to have themselves control everybody else in their blighted belief that they have a right and a set of principles which are the only right and the only set of principles when on the patent evidence of their actions they are wrong. It is my feeling and, I am sure, the feeling of most Australians that everything that can be done to put an end to those who act with violence in all its forms, in all its ways, must be done.

The Indonesian people are proving good neighbours of Australia. There is a growing friendliness between the two nations. We do not agree on everything but, as Senator Evans has just said, Bali has become a loved place in the hearts of many Australians, certainly in the hearts of those of us who have visited the place and enjoyed the hospitality and the remarkable culture of that province of Indonesia. So I too say that we must not be put off from that interrelationship. We must not be put off from the commercial advantage it brings to the people of Bali. We must not be cowed into redirecting ourselves simply because there is this murderous group in Indonesia which should be proscribed. We have proscribed many groups in this Senate because they are terrorists, and there is no doubt JI, whom we presume are behind this outrage, ought to be proscribed by the Indonesian authorities. There are obviously difficulties in weighing that, otherwise the Indonesian government would have done it by now, but I add our word of appeal to the Indonesian government to do just that.

There are arguments that if you repress terrorism it will simply be harder to track down. I think the more favourable argument is that you must repress it as best you can and then deal with the difficulty of tracking down the remnants—those people who will continue to plot behind closed doors to destroy the lives of others so that they may promote some belief that they have.

It remains to be said that we must all hope that those who so far have survived these attacks will get back into life, health and the enjoyment of time with their loved ones. We wish them all a speedy recovery. We support every move the government is making to assist in seeing that the victims of this outrage, of whatever nationality, have the best chance of recovery. We also wish for the greatest support to those who are assisting with transport, with policing and with the delivery of health services wherever they might be—Singapore, Bali, Darwin or elsewhere in Australia. We hope that our efforts, along with those of our friends in Indonesia, mean that this event is never repeated or, if it is repeated—and we must face that that is on the cards—that the power of the terrorists is reduced so that the opportunity is minimised. We hope that Indonesians—like Australians, like people all around the world—can move with safety on the face of this planet because we have respect for each other rather than a hatred that divides and destroys, as it did on Saturday night.

talker.name: Boswell, Sen Ron
talker.role: Leader of The Nationals in the Senate
talker.name: Senator BOSWELL

talk.start.para: —On behalf of The Nationals, I rise to support the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. It fills me with deep sadness to stand here today in the wake of another series of bombings in Bali, not yet three years after the horrific loss of life we witnessed in October 2002 and subsequent bombings in Jakarta of the Marriott Hotel and the Australian embassy. Almost three years ago we assembled in the Great Hall to commemorate the lives lost in the 2002 Bali bombings. At that time I had hoped that the senseless stupidity of the terrorists’ actions would register with those involved and we would not see this type of tragedy repeated. That was a forlorn hope that has not been fulfilled.

speech.para: I extend my sincere sympathy to those Australians who have lost loved ones and those who have suffered injuries from the bombings. At this stage, two Australians are confirmed dead while grave concerns are held for the welfare of two others and 17 Australians have been hospitalised as a result of the attacks. My thoughts and hopes are with those people and their families as they confront this very sad and distressing time.

I also convey my sympathy at the loss of life and casualties suffered by other countries in this attack, especially Indonesia, which suffered the greatest loss of life. The loss of life and the toll from injuries are horrendous in their own right. Beyond this, though, we must feel for the Balinese, who will suffer economic hardship through the loss of tourism.

These horrific bombings have once again shocked our nation to the core. They are acts of extreme cowardice, orchestrated by faceless people and cruelly targeted at innocent men, women and children. There is evidence to suggest the bombs contained nails, glass and ball bearings. Such lethal contents are the hallmark of cold and callous murderers determined to inflict extreme pain and suffering on innocent people. These terrorists harbour unbridled hatred and feel no remorse or sorrow for their victims. Terrorists seek to divide culture, religion and nations with their cowardly acts. They hide behind their fundamentalist beliefs and seek to strike fear amongst our people and undermine our core beliefs in a free and just society.

However, once again in the midst of tragedy and heartbreak we are witnessing acts of bravery, human compassion and regional cooperation. Almost three years ago, the world and especially our region joined together in unprecedented levels of cooperation to assist the victims of the Bali bombings. Once again, it is this human compassion and cooperation that is bringing together nations and cultures in the face of such cowardly terrorist acts. Such compassion and cooperation binds us together as a region and strengthens our resolve against the evil forces of fundamentalism and terrorism.

Immense gratitude must go to the people of Singapore, who so quickly jumped to the aid of Australians caught in the tragedy. Five Australians were immediately moved to Singapore for prompt medical attention in the wake of the bombings. These Australians are receiving the very best care by our friends and neighbours. Two Japanese and two Indonesian casualties have been brought to Australia for medical attention. I commend Australia’s quick response to these bombings. The Australian emergency response team arrived in Bali on 2 October and continues to work under the direction of our consul-general to manage our response.

Initial Australian government aid will go towards helping families and individuals affected by the bombings and will seek to soften the impact of these attacks on the Balinese people and their economy. Australian government assistance provided after the 2002 Bali bombings is already providing immense benefit in dealing with the fallout of Saturday’s bombings with the burns unit that was opened by the Prime Minister on the first anniversary of the Sari Club and Paddy’s Bar bombings being called into action. The Australian government will continue to do all that it can to assist victims, their families and the people of Bali in the wake of these bombings.

Saturday’s Bali bombings further underline the huge fight against terrorism that lies ahead for us. The fight against terrorism will be a long one, but it is one fight that we simply cannot back away from. We owe it to those who lost their lives and suffered so greatly at the hands of cowardly terrorists and their acts to leave no stone unturned in rooting out the underlying causes of terror. The only way we are going to win against terrorism is through close cooperation amongst the world community. This further highlights the critical need for our strong presence and work in countries like Afghanistan and Iraq. The Taliban and Saddam’s regime long harboured terrorists and supported their activities. We must continue the work we started in these countries to ensure that these types of regimes are not able to gain a foothold ever again.

Australia is part of a global coalition against terror and we must remain vigilant in our fight. Since the 9-11 attacks, more than 3,400 international al-Qaeda and associated operatives have been detained or killed in over 100 countries. JI has been listed as a terrorist organisation and 22 of its members have been listed by name. In over 100 countries, tough new terrorist related legislation has been introduced. Within the global coalition, Australia places great emphasis on targeting terrorist cells in our region, and continued cooperation amongst our region’s nations will be critical in the war on terrorism.

I welcome President Yudhoyono’s vocal condemnation of the bombings. I also welcome his stern assurance to the Prime Minister that no effort would be spared by Indonesia in tracking down those responsible.

The Australian way of life is built on strong democratic principles that espouse freedom of speech, freedom of religion and freedom of expression. We are a tolerant nation, but the Australian way, which we all hold so dear, is never to bow to the evils of extremism. As a nation, we will not shy away from helping those who have embarked on the road to democracy. A long-term response will be important. I want to quote Professor Saeed from the University of Melbourne’s department of Islamic studies, who said:

quote.para: To stop it, we have to work together, not just the government, but all of us, together.

speech.para: I support the condolence motion.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of my Democrats colleagues, I also support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, this afternoon. The motion is an expression of our horror at the events that have taken place. Again, we are faced with the senseless, frightening loss of lives and the unimaginable pain and suffering of the many injured and the families and friends who are left to grieve.

speech.para: Today is the time to pause to remember all of those affected by this violence in Bali, and I extend our deepest condolences to them. Democrats Western Australian senator, Andrew Murray, has asked me to make a special mention of the young Western Australian, Brendan Fitzgerald, who lost his life at the tender age of 16. I know that the hearts of every man and woman in this parliament will go out to his family. We offer our sympathies also to the family of Jennifer Williamson from Newcastle, and we hope that Colin and Fiona Zwolinski, also of Newcastle, have not been killed, though there are grave indications that it might be the case that they were blown up by the suicide bomber that struck the restaurant on the beach at Jimbaran. Our thoughts and best wishes are also with those who have been injured, and I wish them the speediest recoveries.

I acknowledge the outstanding work currently being done by all of the medical and service personnel who are caring for and providing assistance on the ground in Bali to not only the Australians who have been affected by this barbarous attack but the Balinese people and those from the many other countries caught up in this suffering. We also thank those involved in bringing back some of the injured to Australia and in caring for them in Darwin hospitals. We congratulate them on their dedication.

This second attack on Bali is an outrage and a tragedy for all. It reminds us once again of the fragility of human life. Behind the bomb blast is a hate and a destructiveness which can be given no quarter in human society and which has no part in our global society in the 21st century. On September 11, 2001 we were all deeply affected by the horrific loss of life from terrorist attacks in New York and Washington DC. Just over a year later, in October 2002, the bomb attacks in Bali brought home the fact that terrorism was happening in our own region and in a place that many Australians visit and hold dear. People of many nationalities were killed and injured in those attacks, but the blow to Australia was particularly broad and brutal.

This second attack highlights the importance of continuing our efforts in the local region. The current assessment by officials is that a terrorist organisation carried out this most recent crime. We do not know for certain whether these bomb blasts can be linked to the Indonesian terrorist group that has links to al-Qaeda: Jemaah Islamiah. We do know that Jemaah Islamiah has previously planned bomb attacks in South-East Asia. This is not a new phenomenon. For many years, extremist groups in South-East Asia, including Jemaah Islamiah, have actively pursued their agendas through violence. We must continue to work with our neighbours, including Indonesia, to develop a coherent, coordinated strategy to address the threat of terrorism and social instability in the Asia-Pacific region. If we are to reduce that threat, we must look for the causes of terrorism and understand their complexity. We cannot overcome deep political, religious and historical divisions that give rise to terrorism but we can play an important role in reducing poverty, alienation, oppression and corruption in those countries.

We must honestly look at the implications of our own foreign and economic policy and that of other nations around the world and ask whether they are appropriate, honest and just and whether changes to those policies might assist in reducing terrorism. We should also remember, too, that suicide bomb attacks are a daily occurrence in countries like Iraq. Our military, strategic and intelligence resources are limited and, in determining how and where they are committed, we must be sensitive to our own important and unique position in this region.

The challenge of terrorism lies within our immediate region and the events in Bali demonstrate just how close this can be. Australia is uniquely placed to offer ongoing assistance. Australia must continue to support Indonesia and other states in our region and be prepared to work closely with them to address the threats to the safety and security of our region. It is not just Australians who are at threat here, of course, but civilians of all nations in our region, most of whom have far fewer resources with which to work towards tackling this threat.

One of the lessons to come from these horrific events is that the best available intelligence on terrorist groups in the region is necessary to prevent attacks. Good intelligence about the terrorists and their operations is absolutely necessary for our security, and we need to make sure that our intelligence agencies are adequately resourced to carry out this difficult and often dangerous work. The challenge is always to reduce risks rather than to inflame tensions and to respect human rights and freedoms in doing so.

I remind all Australians that this attack on innocent civilians on holiday in Bali, like all terrorist attacks, was not the action of a particular religious or ethnic group. I make the plea that all Australians recognise that this was an act of violent, hate-filled extremists who do not represent Muslims or Hindus, Indonesia or Afghanistan or anywhere else. They represent nobody but themselves. No religion should be blamed for this attack. The attack is against the principles of Islam, of Christianity and of other religions. Extremism is the enemy, and it is not reasonable or useful to publicly vilify Muslim communities, or any other group, in Australia.

Permitting and supporting the expression of diverse views is a core value of a liberal democratic society and country, and the best way to fight extremism is through promoting diversity and connectedness between communities. All of us feel a deep sense of anger and a desire to bring to justice those who are responsible for these crimes, but it is critical that we target the terrorists—and only the terrorists.

Over many years, thousands if not millions of Australians have enjoyed the warm hospitality of the Balinese. Prior to 2002, it was common for up to 20,000 Australian tourists to be visiting Bali at any one time. People from many other countries around the globe were also frequent visitors. The 2002 bombing changed all of that. It had a devastating impact on the people of Indonesia and on the economy of Bali. The Indonesian economy, as we know, is fragile and relies heavily on tourism. Tourism in Bali was only just beginning to recover and has now suffered yet another blow.

Those who are responsible for these attacks are no friends of Indonesia. They sought to inflict misery on and deliver hatred to not only those who visit Bali but also the people of Bali who rely on those visitors for their livelihood. No cause—however explained, advocated, twisted or spun—can possibly justify the indiscriminate, unprovoked slaughter of innocent people. A proper response is a measured, sober and effective response, one which brings to justice those who are responsible.

In conclusion, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, I express our heartfelt sympathies to the families who are grieving so terribly at this moment and say to them that your loved ones will be remembered.

talker.name: Fielding, Sen Steve
talker.role: Leader of the Family First Party
talker.name: Senator FIELDING

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Family First Party, I offer condolences to the families of those Australians who were killed in the terrorist attack in Bali on the weekend and also to the families of other victims from Indonesia and other countries. At times like this it is difficult to fully express our horror at such events. The bomb blasts in Bali are of special concern to us in Australia as fellow Australians were killed and many injured. Three Australians are still on the critical list in hospital.

speech.para: These people were ordinary Australians going on a holiday. We can all relate to that. We have all been on family holidays at the beach. We have all enjoyed warmth and relaxation on the sand and special meals out. We all like to escape the pressures of work and daily life and have a couple of weeks break. It is a chance to spend precious time with our partners and our children and perhaps with other relatives and friends, and of course these times provide us with cherished moments.

It is that clash between a very ordinary and familiar scene of a family beach holiday and the indiscriminate violence of bombs which shocks us all. Following the initial shock, when we have the chance to reflect on those horrific events, we find it disturbing that these bomb blasts were very deliberate. They were planned and executed killings, apparently carried out by suicide bombers. I think it is very difficult for us as Australians, in our peaceful part of the world, to understand how someone could carry out such a lethal attack on fellow human beings. It is hard to understand a terrorist thinking such an outrage was so important that they would commit suicide as part of that violence.

Yes, we have seen on our television screens similar horrific events before—in New York, in Baghdad, in Madrid, in London, in Jakarta and, of course, in Bali in 2002. But the high value and dignity we attach to the lives of our fellow human beings mean that such events still have the power to shock—and I hope we never lose the feeling of horror at such events.

Sadly, overseas travel has become more dangerous in some areas because of the threat of terrorism. There is a heavy duty on the federal government to produce timely and accurate travel advice. It is important for travellers to consider that travel information very seriously.

Family First condemns acts of terrorism and supports the government’s efforts to assist the Indonesian authorities to find the perpetrators. I know Australians will keep those people who were victims of the outrage and their families in their thoughts and prayers. I know too that they will be reaching out to support and comfort the survivors who have to live with the injuries and the memories of this most vicious, ugly and senseless slaughter.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion in relation to terrorist attacks in Bali. Like all Australians, it sickened me to learn last Saturday night that there had been another terrorist attack in Bali and on Indonesian soil. It brought back memories of the outrageous attack in October 2002, when many innocent people were killed. In this case, there are two confirmed Australians dead: a 16-year-old boy, Brendan Fitzgerald from Busselton in my home state of Western Australia, and Jennifer Williamson, a mother from Newcastle in New South Wales. There are two Australians unaccounted for, for whom we have grave fears. As has been mentioned by other senators, there are also a number of Australians who remain critically injured.

speech.para: In relation to the response to this matter, I have been very impressed by the speed, efficiency and comprehensive nature of the response by Australian officials and by those men and women working with agencies such as the Department of Defence and the Australian Federal Police. The first Australian Federal Police officer on the scene on Saturday night was our Bali liaison officer, and he was soon followed by seven AFP officers who are permanently based in Jakarta. We had people on the ground quickly during the course of Sunday and Sunday night. As a result of a request from the Indonesian police, the Australian Federal Police have set up a forward command post in Bali and there are now 35 officers there. We have police officers from Western Australia, New South Wales and Victoria, and we appreciate their contribution. Once again, Australian policing is answering the call. We draw upon the expertise and experience of men and women from across the different services to back up the investigation which is now under way.

We have conducted comprehensive surveys of Australian passengers leaving Bali, as we did last time. The Australian Federal Police have interviewed more than 5,000 Australian passengers leaving Bali, and we have found that this has been very useful in gathering evidence. I urge anyone who thinks they might have some information to come forward and to call the hotline number, 1800123400, to put forward that information so that it can be assessed by the Australian Federal Police. We have had a number of pieces of information which have proved extremely useful, be it video or anecdotal evidence from people who have been in Bali.

This is an investigation that is going to require the comprehensive expertise of our police. We now have intelligence officers, bomb blast analysts and forensic experts in Bali. We also have family liaison officers positioned in Bali, Singapore and Darwin, and they have a great deal of experience in dealing with the families and loved ones who are left behind. This is another crucial aspect of the operation, as is disaster victim identification. Yesterday I signed the instrument under the Crimes Act to enable us to use DNA databasing for this. We have seen the great work that our police have done in disaster victim identification recently after the tsunami in our region.

As a result of the great relationship that we have with Indonesian law enforcement agencies, we were able to spring into action very early in the piece and to have direct access to the local authorities. General Made Pastika is leading the local investigation yet again, and of course there are people from the Jakarta Centre for Law Enforcement Cooperation. Australia contributed some $35 million to that centre, which opened last year and we had an extension this year. That has proved its worth in enabling the stationing of officers in Jakarta and the forging of relationships with Indonesian police.

I think it is worth while to remember that the fight against terrorism has been ongoing and the Indonesian police have made some 125 terrorist related arrests over a period of time. Often that goes unnoticed. We certainly are committed to working further with the Indonesian authorities to track down those responsible for this outrageous attack and bring them to justice. I believe that other investigations which we have been involved in have had a great deal of success. I point to the Marriott Hotel bombing, the bombing of our embassy and the bombing which occurred in Bali in October 2002. It is a sad fact that our Australian Federal Police and Australian police generally are getting more experienced in these sorts of attacks. I think that we owe them a debt of gratitude for the great work they do.

I also want to place on record the government’s appreciation for the efforts made by all of those concerned with the response to this attack. I refer to those involved in the treatment of those who were injured and the speedy evacuation not only of the Australian injured but of other nationals as well—and we continue to work in that area. I also refer to those officials across our departments—Centrelink and others—who have done a fantastic job in dealing with the many inquiries that we have experienced, and of course to those officials in our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, particularly at the consulate in Bali. Also, I have been advised of the volunteers. Yet again our local expats on the ground in Bali, who did such a great job last time, are coming forward and helping at the consulate. I think that this demonstrates the great Australian character that we know only too well in times of adversity.

This attack just strengthens our resolve not only to catch those who are responsible but also to continue the fight against terrorism. This is a fight which will go on for some time. It will take a very long time before this war is won. Win it we will, but it will only occur with combined efforts, and I greatly appreciate the cooperation that the Australian Federal Police has received from not only the Indonesian authorities but policing across Australia.

The investigation is in its early stages. There are a number of leads which are being pursued, but I would caution those people who listen to rumours and take them as fact. We have to be very careful. In this environment you will have rumours abounding in relation to arrests and other things. Today it was reported that there had been an arrest. I can confirm that there has not been such an arrest. There have also been reports of rumours circulating in Bali on Saturday night. We have had no specific intelligence on this attack and I think we have to be very careful of what we take as fact and what is rumour. If we were to work by every rumour that occurred, if we were to take notice of any rumour that came to our attention and act accordingly, then things indeed would come to a standstill.

This has been, yet again, an outrageous attack, which has had as its victims not only foreigners to Indonesia but in the main, in the majority, Indonesians. It is very much an attack on Indonesia, on Indonesian democracy, and indeed it is an outrage against all civilised people.

talk.start.para: —As the foreign affairs spokesperson of the Australian Democrats, I rise to support the condolence motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate and in particular to pay tribute to those people involved in the rescue and relief efforts. Senator Ellison has just done an excellent job of outlining what those efforts involve. I think there is nothing so sad in what we do in this place as when we have to deal with these condolence motions, especially when we are talking about the death of Australian citizens.

speech.para: I extend our deepest sympathies, as my leader has done, to the people of Bali, to the people of Indonesia and to all those people who have been affected by this senseless act but in particular to those Australian families and communities who have lost loved ones, who know victims or, indeed, who are victims themselves. This terrorist act has shown us, once again, that terrorism recognises no race or religion, does not distinguish between men and women or civilians and military and neither is it a respecter of age. Terrorism is a threat faced by all nations and all peoples.

For those of us who heard the news on Saturday night or woke to those awful images on Sunday morning, this has reopened deep wounds. As Senator Hill and Senator Evans have pointed out, Bali is a special place for Australians. It is a favoured destination for many Australians for holidays, not just because of its natural beauty but of course because of its wonderful people, who once again are suffering as a consequence of this attack. That is one reason that our anger and dismay are so strong and our memories of 12 October 2002 are so great.

For many of us, this condolence debate and the events with which we are dealing are reminiscent of September 11—and what a desperately sad day and debate that was for many of us. It does not matter how many times this happens, the grief and anger for people who are affected remains incredibly raw. As many times as this happens, the grief is not alleviated nor is the impact lessened, so of course it reminds all of us to work together in a cooperative and constructive way to try and combat this evil of terrorism. There is no cause, no ideal nor any principle that could possibly justify such barbarity. You have to remember, as Senator Boswell has pointed out, that this chilling attack was deliberately designed not only to kill but to maim.

The contrast between those capable of such acts and those who risked their lives to provide help in the aftermath of the bombing could not be more pronounced. In the face of such barbarity there is great comfort in witnessing even some of the simple acts of compassion that emerged from the horror. I think the human spirit does remain pretty unbeaten, uncowed and unbowed in that respect.

On behalf of the Democrats, I want to particularly congratulate the governments and the emergency services of both our country and Indonesia for their immediate and very effective responses. Within minutes of the attack, emergency services from Indonesia were already mobilised and ready to provide all possible assistance and, within hours, medical professionals and emergency workers from Australia were leaving their own families and friends and boarding planes on their way to Bali.

As people have pointed out, this is one way we will combat terrorism, one way that I hope we will defeat it—through such cooperation and such strength. Today I think we all do reaffirm our resolve to tackle terrorism in all its forms and tackle not only its consequences but its root causes. I hope that we will work together to prevent further attacks. In closing, again I extend my deepest sympathies not only to the Australian families who have lost people in this tragic event but of course to the victims, in Australia and elsewhere.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Hill in relation to the terrible acts that took place in Bali last Saturday night. I wish to speak very briefly to them. In my role as Chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and also as acting chair of our intelligence and security committee I can say that this issue has, in fact, been on our minds for the past three years. During the life of the last parliament, we had a watching brief on the war on terrorism in which we looked carefully at ways in which Australians can react and respond to the acts of terrorism that might take place within our country and overseas. One can only wonder at what goes through the distorted mind of an extremist, a terrorist, who is prepared to take their own life and the lives of many others in the despicable acts that we have seen not only in Bali but in various other places throughout the world in recent times.

speech.para: One of the things that came out of the inquiry that the committee conducted was that it is obvious that, if a person is determined to take their own life, it is very difficult to thwart the consequences of their action in doing so. So we have the situation that occurred in Bali last Saturday night, where the lives of innocent children and parents, both foreigners—Australians and Japanese—and Indonesians, their fellow citizens, were taken indiscriminately by people whose distorted minds suggested that, in taking their own lives, they were entitled to take the lives of as many other people as they wanted in order to press home a particularly political personal point of view.

I do not know what makes people do that, and neither do most people. But the fact is that it has happened, and it has happened again and again throughout the world—and particularly in Bali. We think of September 11 and the first Bali bombings in October 2002. It is not the number of people who have been killed or maimed; it is the fact that it has happened again and again. It is the event we feel sorry about, not the total numbers that have been killed, maimed or affected in such a way. My sympathy goes to the families of those involved—the Australian families and the international families—and particularly to the Balinese and Indonesian families. They are the ones who will suffer the most. Their suffering will not be just on Saturday night; their suffering will be ongoing over the next few years as their economy suffers from the downturn that will inevitably take place in tourism to Bali.

At times I too I think it would be good if people were to ignore the danger and to continue to travel to Bali. But the government is committed to giving travel advisories. The government is committed to warning citizens that if they choose to travel there they must take note of the risk that is involved. I was part of a small group that went to a conference six months after the last bombings when the Balinese economy was in terrible shape. Some 85 per cent of the people on that island rely on tourism for their income. They rely on tourism to make a living so that their families can survive. At that conference, they were looking at ways and means of restarting the influx of tourists to that island. It has taken a long time. It was just starting to return to pre-2002 levels and then, all of a sudden, we had an event like this which will put them back to where they were in October 2002—and probably further behind.

I think of those Balinese who are going to suffer not only this weekend but over the next few years while their economy recovers and while they try and get over the shock of such an event happening again. They will also have to try to get over the horrific injuries and mutilations caused by the devastating types of bombs that were set off. They had ball bearings and other sorts of shrapnel in them which caused horrible wounds. My heart goes out to them. It reminds us of our vulnerability. It reminds us that we must do everything we can to try to thwart the activities of people who perpetrate such horrific acts against their fellow innocent citizens. I conclude by once again offering my condolences to all the families which have lost loved ones and to those who will live on but who will be horribly mutilated because of the events that took place last Saturday night.

talk.start.para: —I also rise to support the motion moved by Senator Hill on behalf of the government and the opposition on the recent bombings in Bali. Busselton and Newcastle are almost as far away from each other as any two Australian towns can be, but today they are united in grief, and the rest of the nation is in solidarity with them. The terrible atrocities we have seen in Bali over the weekend have, so far as the reports say, taken the lives of at least two Australians, while grave fears are held for a couple from Newcastle. The bombings come almost three years after the 2002 attacks on Bali. Like then, this latest tragedy has left Australians shocked and saddened by the loss of innocent life and the terrible depths that terrorists are prepared to sink to.

speech.para: From coast to coast, I know that today our hearts go out to the families who have lost loved ones and those who have sustained injuries. In Busselton, the community is in shock at the loss of 16-year-old Brendan Fitzgerald. From reports, Brendan was at the time sharing a meal with his father, Terry, and his 13-year-old sister, Jessica, in a cafe at Kuta when the blasts occurred. Both Terry and Jessica were taken to hospital in Singapore. Terry, from reports, is in a critical condition with serious injuries, while Jessica regained consciousness yesterday after suffering burns and shrapnel wounds. Brendan’s death is part of a double blow for Busselton. The town also lost a much-loved teacher, Carol Johnstone, in the 2002 Bali attack.

On the other side of the country, Newcastle is mourning the loss of 48-year-old mother Jennifer Williamson. Ms Williamson was holidaying in Bali with her husband, Bruce, who was seriously injured and is being treated, also in Singapore. Also missing—and grave fears for them are held—is Newcastle couple Colin and Fiona Zwolinski. Many more have been injured or exposed to the scenes in the awful aftermath of the attacks. A lot of people are going to need the support and love of the community in the wake of this atrocity, and our thoughts are with them. As we have done before, Australians will rally around to protect, heal and assist our fellow Australians and their families.

Australians have long favoured Bali, as I think many of the speakers today have also said, as one of the region’s most beautiful and popular holiday spots. But it is not only the beautiful beaches that draw Australians in; it is also the charm and friendly nature of the Balinese people. I hope that, just like after the 2002 bombings, the bond between Australia and Indonesia will in fact grow stronger. I know at the moment that Australian military personnel, police, consulate staff and other officials will be doing their utmost to assist the victims and their families in whatever way they can. They have been very rapid in their response to this latest atrocity in Bali—it has been a very skilled and rapid response which I am sure all Australians would be proud of and thankful for. Thanks go to Commissioner Keelty for his rapid response and his ability to engage quickly in this matter.

I recall sitting in this chamber and listening to a similar condolence motion following the 2002 attack. I also remember attending a commemorative service for the 88 Australians who lost their lives in that attack. Before that, we did the same after September 11, when four Australians were killed. In the recent London bombings, one Australian died and many others were injured. It is a terrible statistic that nearly 100 Australians have been killed by terrorists since September 11.

It is clear that we have learnt some important lessons from the 2002 attack, but on the weekend we were reminded that the threat of terror in our region is a very real one. Sadly, Australians continue to be at risk of terrorist attacks, as Saturday night’s attack demonstrates. But this attack was not aimed just at Australians or other Western tourists; it was also an attack against democracy generally, against the Indonesian secular state and against the Balinese people themselves. The hardest hit by these attacks are the Indonesians. Each time one of these attacks occurs, it creates uncertainty for international investors and particular hardship for those whose livelihood depends on a healthy tourist trade.

There are still gaps in our intelligence, and we must work towards continuous improvement in this area. We must look to work together not just with our Indonesian counterparts but across South-East Asia and the rest of the world to continue the search-and-destroy mission that all responsible countries are undertaking against such groups as Jemaah Islamiah and al-Qaeda. At home we have to always be looking for the gap in our defences and do as well as we can—and better than that where we can, as well. Measures such as strengthening our borders and ports and strengthening security at airports, public places and events are an obvious must. From Labor’s perspective we should extend our thanks to and recognise the dedication of the Australian Federal Police, who are now working in Bali and at home in the fight against terrorism.

Finally, I want to send a message to the terrorists themselves: your actions are futile. Our democracy is strong. It cannot be shaken by your hate and bombs. We will stand beside the Indonesian government in our determination to bring you to justice.

talk.start.para: —I, too, wish to support the motion and extend my condolences and support to the families of all of those either killed or injured by these outrageous and barbaric acts of terrorism. There is, and Australia is an active combatant in, a war on terror, and the events of this last weekend in Bali confirmed for all why this war must go on and why every Australian must be vigilant and committed to this fight. Three apparently synchronised explosions took place in Bali at about 7.30 pm on Saturday, 1 October. These devices were apparently detonated by suicide bombers at Jimbaran Bay and at Kuta. I was at Jimbaran Bay in May last year, observing the election process on Bali, a beautiful island with beautiful people who, at that time, were only seeking to exercise their democratic right in a peaceful, proper and appropriate way.

speech.para: These bombs have taken the lives of—at this time—two Australians and injured some 17 others. There has been confirmation that a 16-year-old Busselton boy, Brendan Fitzgerald, was one of those killed. The other was a 48-year-old woman from New South Wales, Jennifer Williamson. My heart, my sympathy and my sense of anger and frustration go out to their families—particularly to Brendan’s father, Terry, and mother, Lisa. They are both from Busselton. As I speak, Terry is fighting for his life in a Singapore hospital, having sustained severe internal and other shrapnel related injuries as a result of the explosion. Of course, he was standing next to his beloved son when the explosion occurred. Similarly, Brendan’s 13-year-old sister, Jessica, has suffered severe burns and internal shrapnel injuries. She is also in a Singapore hospital, grappling to survive.

I can advise the Senate that Terry’s parents, Trevor and Win Fitzgerald, have flown to Singapore to be with their family, as has Brendan and Jessica’s mother, Lisa. I say to the Fitzgerald family on behalf of all Western Australians: we are all thinking of you, we share your grief and we acknowledge the battle that you are enduring as you confront personally the tragedy and pain of this atrocity. We are some thousands of miles away, but you must forever now bear the pain and loss of losing Brendan in Bali.

My good friend and colleague the state member for Vasse, Mr Troy Buswell, provided what assistance he could to the Fitzgerald family before they departed for Singapore. Troy tells me that the Federal Police were quickly on the scene to assist the Fitzgeralds, allocating an AFP liaison officer to assist the family, as I understand it, through these terrible events and the processes in Indonesia and Singapore. I want to say what a wonderful effort our AFP have undertaken in the very short time that I have been aware of what has been going on up there. It is three or four days later and I am already hearing from a devastated family how grateful they are to the Australian Federal Police. Can I also say to DFAT and embassy and consular staff in Bali and Singapore: congratulations on also receiving the accolades of a very grateful family.

I want to acknowledge in passing the good work of our AFP Commissioner, Mr Mick Keelty, and Senator Chris Ellison, who is here today in the chamber. The AFP was ready, willing and able to anticipate such a terrible event and it swung straight into action. I am very pleased that the government that I am a part of has been able to respond so successfully. I also congratulate parliamentary secretary Bruce Billson on the good work that he and DFAT have done in fulfilling their duties.

I am aware that all injured Australians have now been evacuated through the assistance of the Australian Defence Force. Defence immediately provided a medical assistance team in support of the government’s emergency response team and was in the field by approximately 1.30 pm on Sunday. The accounts that I have indicate that these deployments have been significant and timely. I commend our Australian Defence Force and Minister Hill on their obvious preparedness and their responsiveness. I also say that, commercially, Qantas managed to marshal many planes into the air to get to Bali to assist Australians to come home, and I want to thank them for that.

I want to extend my condolences to all of the families of those killed and injured and also, importantly, to the people of Bali—a beautiful island, as I have said, the home of a peace loving and gentle people. As I have said, I was in Bali last year watching their local and regional elections. There was no violence, no bombings and no terror, just an expression of a will to vote peacefully and to advance their little corner of the world through commerce and tourism. I know all Australians share my concern as to their future wellbeing and viability in the face of these atrocities. They share all of the qualities of the victims of terror: they were innocent; they did nothing to incite or deserve this attack; they were randomly Hindu, Muslim and Christian; they were men and women; they were young and old; and, of course, many of them were children. It is a disgrace. My hope is that the Indonesian government can become better able to root out the extremists and provocateurs behind the perpetrators of these ridiculous acts. I know that the Australian government are ready, willing and able to assist our neighbour in any and every way that we can.

talk.start.para: —In supporting this motion, I speak as the chair of the Australia-Indonesia parliamentary friendship group and also having grown up in the community of Busselton, which has again been directly affected by an act of terrorism in Bali. I have been to Bali several times and have lived for many years in the town of Port Hedland, which has direct flights to Bali and is closer to Bali than to Perth. So today I speak also on behalf of the people of the Pilbara, who have a very special place in their hearts for Bali and the Balinese people.

speech.para: Firstly, I wish to extend my condolences to the Fitzgerald family of Busselton. The Fitzgeralds’ 16-year-old son, Brendan, tragically died in the blast at the Kuta Square restaurant. His 13-year-old sister, Jessica, suffered severe burns, and their father, Terry, remains in a critical condition in a Singapore hospital. I am sure that all members of the parliamentary friendship group will wish to join me in extending our sympathies to the mother of this family, Lisa Fitzgerald, and would want her and the people of Busselton to know that our thoughts are with them once again as that town mourns victims of terrorism in Bali. As chair of the Australia-Indonesia parliamentary friendship group and on behalf of the members of parliament who belong to that group, I have to say that I have been greatly disturbed by these events.

As many will be aware, the Balinese are Hindus, not Muslims, and the Balinese are just as much victims of these Muslim extremists as are the Western visitors to the island. In the long term, it will be the people of Bali who suffer the most from this attack because tourism is a key, vital part of the Balinese economy, and the ultimate outcome of this attack will be some degree of adverse impact on tourism and therefore on the Balinese economy and the standard of living of the Balinese people.

More than anything else, as the Prime Minister has said, this bombing represents an attack on the process of democratisation in Indonesia. The last thing Muslim extremists want is a free, democratic and secular Indonesia, which, while religiously tolerant, will not tolerate the actions of Muslim extremists. I join others who have congratulated the President of Indonesia, Dr Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, on the progress that he has made towards consolidating democracy in Indonesia and assure him of our continuing support in his endeavours to ensure that a democratic, tolerant and secular Indonesian state prevails in spite of these terrorist attacks.

talk.start.para: —Senator Brown has already spoken on behalf of the Greens to add our condolences. He has acknowledged the work of people in the AFP and our defence forces and the work of the volunteers and other medical people who are assisting with these issues, and he acknowledged the trauma for the families of the people of Bali, Indonesia and other countries who are affected. As a senator for New South Wales, I want to make brief mention of the seven families in Newcastle who have injured, missing or deceased family members. Newcastle has suffered traumas and disasters in the past, and our thoughts are with those families and their friends, particularly the children whose parents have experienced injuries, as they go through this period.

speech.para: It is also worth thanking the church and the school in Newcastle which have been at the forefront of trying to provide opportunities for those families and children to come together to share and experience their grief as a way of healing and getting through these experiences. I want to put on the record our condolences to all those families in Newcastle. There are two families from Batemans Bay in New South Wales who have members who have suffered injuries as a result of the tragedy on the weekend, and our condolences also go to them.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the people of Victoria I also extend my condolences to the families of those who died in this terrible tragedy and to those who are fighting for their lives at the moment. I am sure all Victorians would join me in that.

speech.para: There was some talk earlier about visits to Bali, of rites of passage and family holidays. Some have done one, some have done the other, and some, like me, have done both. I think that the great tragedy of the weekend was that again it was innocent people who bore the brunt of this outrageous attack. They are not the decision makers. They are not members of parliament. They are not members of anti-Islam groups. They are innocent people.

Cate and the kids and I were over in Bali two years ago, and it was a big decision for us to make to go back there after 2002. We spent about 10 days using the services of a Balinese man called Ktut—and I know that there are lots men called Ktut in Bali, but this was a very special one. This man had put his life savings into a van that would carry families of our size. He had risked all. During those 10 days, he told me stories, probably previously untold stories, of the people—not the people we saw in the press after 2002—who are still confined to small villages all over Bali, many of them without limbs, and many incapable of living a proper life again. And I am sure I speak for everyone when I say that when I woke up and heard this news I said, ‘Why is it that it is always the innocent people who suffer in these outrageous attacks?’ I think that there are now probably two, maybe three, generations of Australians who have an affinity with Bali. I think that, of all the people throughout the world who were prepared to return to Bali after 2002, it was predominantly Australians who were prepared to do so.

The Balinese are a people who absolutely, fundamentally, rely on tourism to survive, and that is why I would urge the Indonesian President to make sure that we do outlaw JI. I respect the fact that that is the Indonesian government’s decision, but I think we would all implore them to do so because, until we can again guarantee the safety of Australians in places like Bali, decisions will be made by ordinary Australians which will, potentially, impact on the livelihood of those Balinese and those decisions, regrettably, will be to not return to Bali. I do not think we can expect our fellow Australians to be Balinese tourism martyrs. I do not think it is fair of us to stand in this place and implore people to support the people of Bali when they will be going through a very difficult decision-making process about whether to return there. For the people of Bali, we must see more of what we have seen today, and that is a united front to tackle the terror of terrorism.

In conclusion, I do want to support Senator Allison’s comments today. She quite rightly said that, again, it is absolutely essential that the moderate Muslim community in this country is not tarred with the brush of that atrocity. We, in this place and in the other place, must use every endeavour we can to ensure that that is not an outcome of what occurred over the weekend.

talk.start.para: —The medical community in Western Australia are experiencing a mixture of emotions today. They are celebrating the award of a well-deserved Nobel prize for medicine. But the same hospital where the award-winning discovery was made is yet again on standby, preparing to assist wherever necessary more innocent victims of terrorism in our region.
